Award.AwardTitle: AIR: Sophisticated Electronic Markets for TV Advertising, Powered by Novel Optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project utilizes advances in key classic computer science problems such as search tree restructuring to implement an optimized auction system for acquisition/sale of media advertising time. The proposed system would move away from the current manually negotiated approach to an expressive auction approach in which buyers can express rich preferences and constraints through which they can more effectively conduct their campaigns. The optimization software of the PI currently underlies the nationwide kidney exchange. This effort will scale and adapt the PI's prior work in expressive auctions for transportation and medical markets to match the richness of the TV market. Based on requirements gathering to be undertaken, a prototype application for the TV ad market will be completed.

The proposed work has the potential to reap significant savings though efficiencies and added derived value obtained for the expressive auction approach. This is anticipated by the PI to be anywhere from 13-41% of the current $75B market. Moreover, implementation of these approaches has the potential to create fairer and open markets while consumers benefit from viewing of ads relevant to their interests and needs. The approach has broader application in other areas such as electricity and pollution rights/credits as well as other media markets. The effort has a relationship within an established innovation ecosystem at CMU and a new small company will be launched.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project team successfully developed the optimization technology, market designs, and software prototypes for advertising campaigns sales, inventory allocation, and scheduling systems that can handle both refined targeting and campaign controls. This renders unnecessary the tradeoffs between targeted advertising and guaranteed advertising campaigns because with this technology and paradigm one can achieve the best of both worlds. The technology covers TV (linear and nonlinear), Internet display, mobile, game, radio, and cross-media advertising.

The approach can be used to support sales by a manual direct sales force, to support programmatic sales, and to support settings where multiple sales forces (e.g., manual and programmatic, and/or local, regional, and national) sell into the same inventory. The optimizer can automatically decide what inventory is allocated to which sales channel dynamically, thereby obviating the need to inefficiently earmark inventory ahead of time to the different channels.

A startup company, Optimized Markets, Inc., was successfully founded based on this project. The company has conducted several successful commercial pilot tests with major Multi-System Operators (i.e., cable TV companies) and companies on the TV broadcaster side. These pilots --- where Optimized Markets’s systems were benchmarked against status quo systems and new software offerings by other vendors --- indicate that Optimized Markets’s systems are the only ones that can truly optimize under the full complexity of these markets. Revenue lifts of 20%-30% were achieved over status quo, and the ad campaigns better met the advertisers’ and agencies’ constraints and preferences. Furthermore, the process is easier for all parties due to more accurate sales, faster sales processes, fewer makegoods and preemptions, avoidance of exposure problems, and automation.

The approach also applies to other combinatorial sales and market setting such as electricity markets and pollution credit markets. After a careful prioritization of the business opportunities through strategic analysis and a series of meetings with potential customers in the different markets, the team decided to pursue advertising as the main first market.
